title: Which team will win Super Bowl LII?
preds: 65 seconds left. Even the Pats can’t do it. 8 point game
Fumbles matter, much as I hate to say it (Vikings fan). One way or the other, I will be wrong.
Probability that Patriots can repeat declines each season Brady gets older.
Updating after Philadelphia field goal that put them up 6.
Updating on account of New England cutting Philadelphia's lead to 3 at 29-26.
3 point game. I’ve seen the Pats come back too many times to count them out. I don’t like Brady but an unstoppable team.
third q contestable touchdown seals it
expressions of frustration from Patriots third quarter.

Updating on account of Philadelphia going into halftime with a 10-point lead. ESPN's win probability tracker is currently giving the Eagles a 78 percent chance of winning. I am bumping them down slightly on account of Brady and Belichick's Super Bowl experience and past comebacks--variables that, to the best of my knowledge, are taken into account in ESPN's win probability algorithm.

picking a side
- got first touchdown
- held lead into the second

So this is not what I *want* to see happen but I think 2018 will be a down year for the stock market and working backwards from the Super Bowl indicator (if P then Q) that says an AFC team wins in those years ~80%. (If Q then P).
Because a friend who knows a lot said so. Also, Pats offense is able to  beat most deffenses.
slight change accounting for gronkowski's availability.
This team has overcome injuries all season. Yet, the players continue to perform. The Eagles defense is superb.
Tom Brady.  History of success with this quarterback and coach.
Philadelphia has the better defense but New England's offense can score on anyone.  Likelihood of a Philadelphia offensive mistake is higher.
The front 4 of the eagles is very dominant.  The Patriots OLine will be unable to protect Tom Brady.  The Eagles' DLine will overwhelm the Patritots' OLine.

Jaguars and Vikings are out of the game, also there is a high correlation between the patriots win when wearing white uniforms and also they have a higher super bowl win percentage over all other teams in the last decade.

All year long N.E.  has been coming from behind in the 4th quarter, counting on tiring the defenses.  The Eagles have a 6-7 man rotation on their 4 man front and will hurry Brady enough to negate that advantage.
Also, the Eagles coaches will call a game to allow Nick Foles to shred the Patriots defense
I'm wondering about Tom Brady's 'bad' hand. It seems quite better now. But there was a small window where  it lowered the bookie odds.

I think the Eagles have a better chance to win this game than the odds would suggest, primarily because their defense has the ability to put pressure on Brady and cover New England's receivers.   Nick Foles was the Eagles' star quarterback years ago before a slow start and an injury launched him on an improbable odyssey through the NFL and back to Philly just in the "nick" of time for another incredible feat.  He has stepped up through the playoff's and I like his chances to pull off an upset.

The game will be close.  All but one New England Super Bowl with Belichick and Brady has been won or lost by 4 points or less.  The Eagles will move the ball, but I don't think they will score enough points since New England excels at preventing teams from scoring.  I think the Eagles benefitted from Minnesota's hangover in the NFC championship game, so I see that scoring outburst as an aberration.  Jacksonville's defense was better than the Eagles defense and the Patriots still found a way to win.  The close game will give the Eagles a chance, but I don't think they can rely on their QB to win them the game.
I am rooting for an interesting game. As a NY Giants fan, I hate both these teams, but unfortunately one of them has to win.
I think the underdog factor is huge here.  The Eagles are flying!
I want anyone but Brady to win but he does always manage to pull it out whatever he has to do to do it.

Disclosure: My prediction was made after the Division Championships, so Jacksonville and Minnesota had been eliminated. First, using the oddsmakers predictions combined with other statistics-based institutions' predictions (individuals who are much more versed in these teams than I am), I gave the Patriots an initial score of 60-40.  The remaining 5% I added to the Patriots because I feel the statistics may be missing the New England Patriots' ability to prevent opposing offenses from scoring over the latter half of the season. Their defense started the year historically bad, but improved drastically by the end of the season. Combining that with the team having two weeks to prepare, and I anticipate that the Patriots will win in a close game.
Brady and Belichick know not only what it takes to win that game, but how to come back from a rocky start.

The Eagles go into this year's Superbowl as the clear underdogs, so, all else being equal, it is much more likely that the Patriots will win:  "The Patriots have won five Super Bowls - all under the team of quarter-back Tom Brady and head coach Bill Belichick. The Eagles have got to two Super Bowls but they haven't won any. Their last Super Bowl appearance came in 2004 when they lost to the Patriots." https://www.express.co.uk/sport/othersport/913955/Super-Bowl-how-long-is-match-when-will-it-finish-half-time OTHER CONTEXT THAT MIGHT AFFECT THESE BASE ODDS: -Fox News are backing the Patriots to win, arguing that Tom Brady's age does not affect their chances, and that his experience put them at an advantage. http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2018/02/03/dr-marc-siegel-tom-brady-and-patriots-will-win-super-bowl-heres-why.html -538 prediction is 58% Patriots, and his predictions have been 80% accurate throughout the tournament, so heavy weight should be held by what he says. 
http://uk.businessinsider.com/nate-silver-picks-new-england-patriots-to-win-super-bowl-2018-1?r=US&IR=T Will be updating as new info comes through.

Correcting a previous forecast, as I am not a huge follower of football and had missed that Wentz was out due to injury in week 14. After reading up on Nick Foles and how he's been able to integrate with the Eagles' starting line late in the season, I think there is still a good probability of Foles and the Eagles pulling out a win. One major advantage would be the limited game tape on Foles, making him more unpredictable from a defensive planning view point. Foles also beats the rest of the pack for time to pass, being even quicker than Brady, making the odds of a few good blitz/rush plays being implemented by the Patriots, less likely.
Brady will get sacked many times, and he will tire.

Eagles are better player for player minus quarterback and gronk position for position.  Further, the crazy stunts that happen at the end of patriots games are a typical.  Regression to the mean is due with the patriots.  Eagles win big.

The Patriots are the stronger team at every skill position, and a superior front at the line of scrimmage on both sides of the ball.  The Eagles have an outside chance based on opportunistic defense, but it is slight.  Patriots 28-14.

On this one, the better information we can have is following the line odds (betting) along the time since opening and tracking the amount of money.
And analyzing this itens we can see that the big money are on the eagles (at least 4 1M$ bets reported) moving the open line from +6 to +4.5.
time for New England to lose

While the current prediction tides and bets are favoring the New England Patriots as the safe bet, there are some advanced computer models favoring the Eagles, surprisingly, in a bit over 60% of cases. https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/2018-nfl-super-bowl-odds-and-picks-advanced-computer-model-loving-under-in-patriots-vs-eagles/
I can never predict sports any better than 50-50 but 538 has it 58% eagles and he made his money predicting sports so it seems a good bet.

Brady's winning track record would indicate that he may be able to lead the team out of an unforeseen rut and/or lead a strong last minute drive, if needed. Wentz is still fairly new to the NFL when compared with Brady, and does not have the same level of high pressure game experience, though his higher than average wonderlic score of 40 (compared to Brady's 33), may be enough to help him out of difficult situations. I nearly did 50/50 as there are many unknowns from injury reserve (4 Patriots are still questionable - not to mention Brady's recently operated-hand, where-as only 1 Eagle is on IR), to unforeseen game-day injuries.

This is roughly the implied probability based on the betting odds I just saw. I can't figure out how I could adjust it any better myself.  Perhaps for some events, one could imagine that more people put money on 1 team, because they're a fan of the team...and the odds could reflect that. But for the Superbowl...online sports gambling sites have a large liquid market.

Eagles have a great defense but they get most of their pressure on the edges, historically this has not worked against Tom Brady. Also they are mostly a zone defense which also is not the best approach to Brady. Other than the Seahawks, the teams that have beat Brady have deployed aggressive man-to-man and got pressure up the middle. Still the Pats defense is vulnerable and the Eagles have great playmakers on D, that's why the Eagles have a chance.
I'm a sports fan that keeps track of these teams and listens to experts.
Eagles want it more. Tom Brady has the shaky hand syndrome going into this one.
They are simply the better team

Historical NE performance, strong yet unstable Phil performance. This is post AFC/NFC games, so Jacksonvill and Minnesota have been removed. Hedging against NE due to Gronk injury. I think the favorite in this game could swing if he is inactive/ineffective.

The Eagles will come out strong and fast, but they will not be able to compete with the Patriots over the course of the game. The Patriots have Tom Brady who is determined to win another Super Bowl before he retires and has the ability to pull the craziest stunts under pressure.
The Patriots have Tom Brady; he can pull the craziest stunts out of nowhere.
they won against the eagles in 2005 super bowl. they have only lost 3 of 9 super bowl games
Patriots are listed as a slim favorite to win.
Eagles are an unknown to me, but knowing the patriots history, (even if i dont care for them), they have the odds in their favor.

Strange to be updating this after the previous round.  I like New England for two reasons.  One is their coach and QB, as everyone knows.  Second, is the Eagles may not get the same amazing game from Foles they got last week.  He is good but not that good.
Football is a game of chance..
Tom Brady is on a one man tear through the NFL record books. It will continue.
The Patriots have demonstrated both in playoffs and in the regular season that even against elite defenses, they are able to break them down in the second half and find a way to win.

New England has demonstrated the ability to rally at critical times - their greatest strength is their QB who has the mental stamina to overcome PHI's best strength, their defense. PHI's QB and offense have put up good performances, but these seem to be more outlier events and while it is certainly possible they can do it again, even if they do, there is a chance NE will win, and if not, NE will most likely have more points on the board.
NFL wants Golden Boy to win.
average of betting site paddypower.com odds, (2/1 New England), and pattern of win-loss ratio, (50/50)

Brady cannot step up into pocket, because of Eagles middle rush with Fletcher and Tim, disrupts his game. Bill will plan for this with bubble screens, that we get covered by Eagles outside LB team.  Foles loves warmer environment and has another great game. Plus at 40 long season finally catches up to Brady.
I picked a heck of a time to boycott NFL.

4th quarter show down, Brady sidelined early in 4th quarter, (hamstring/left knee issue). Under a minute left, Philly gets a break from a misfire call, and comes up with the ball after blown coverage deep. Philly wins by 2 points.
Upping Philly to 20%. Pats still best overall (IMO) but Eagles looking good.
Dang you Tom Brady - just cover the spread!

Updating my forecast again after Philadelphia's win over Minnesota. Betting lines currently have the Patriots as 5.5-point favorites, which translates to a 69 percent change of victory. FiveThirtyEight's forecast is currently giving the Patriots a 58 percent chance of winning. To create my forecast, I took an average of the two and then grossed up the Eagles' chances slightly on account of their impressive margin of victory today.

Obviously, I overestimated the abilities of the Vikings on offense. As such, I still think NE is the favorite in this match-up, even if the Eagles prefer to be considered underdogs in the match and view it as an advantage.
Not a fan of the Pats but I have to acknowledge they are a great team with a strong coach. While only 10% for Eagles, I’d prefer they win...
Bias. Hate Cheating Tom Brady. He deserves an *ing.
Updating on account of New England defeating Jacksonville earlier today.

The Jaguars currently hold the ball and are leading the Patriots 14-10 with about 13 minutes left in the 3rd quarter. According to ESPN's win probability tracker, they have a 63 percent chance of winning. However, given the Patriots history, I am still going to consider them slight favorites to make it to the Super Bowl. I chose 25 percent for both the Eagles and the Vikings because those are the odds given by FiveThirtyEight's NFL forecast model.
using today's money lines to come up with % chance to win tomorrow and combining with likely money lines for super bowl matchups.

I'm being biased by the weighting shown on the previous page to give the Patriots an edge. For the rest I just distributed equally. I haven't followed the NFL at all this year so I have no real basis for a more informed decision.

Why am I making this forecast? I don't know. I hate football and vowed to avoid it last time I got smashed on the Kaepernick question. But New England stands out. Was it @SneakyPete I followed? Yes, but he sneakily switched sides to avoid getting smashed. I learned from that (hopefully).  ;-)

Generally going with the oddsmakers on this one (http://www.espn.com/chalk/story/_/id/18614149/nfl-latest-odds-all-32-teams-win-super-bowl-lii), but I also like the Eagles, so a little intuition mixed in there.

Always tough on Qs like this to keep preferences out of the estimate.  I don't care about any of this, which makes me less susceptible to that bias.  It does not, however, make me in any useful sense knowledgeable.

I don’t like them (inflategate) and my wife reminds me too often how cute Brady is but unfortunately they have the coaching, the quarterback, and the overall team. They s/b 100% but I just like Minnesota more (so 10%) on a Hail Mary.

NE has proven itself capable of putting together a championship caliber team for the past 7 years, and thus is the likely front runner.  JAX has an excellent defense, but their offense is inconsistent under Bortles, and thus is a weakness.  MIN has an excellent defense as well, and a coherent offense capable of making big plays, but also getting stymied (as happened last week against NO).  PHI has a good defense, but inconsistent play under Foles on offense. It's hard to determine if their win against ATL was more a function of their offense coming together, or the inconsistent play that has plagued ATL and Matt Ryan throughout the years. In the AFC/NFC championships, I think MIN is more likely to beat PHI than vice versa. JAX poses a formidable threat to NE, but the match up is more of NE Off vs JAX Def. NE's Def has improved throughout the season, and JAX's fate depends on which version of Bortles shows up on Sunday. Thus, I think NE beats JAX, but it will likely be a close game with little offense by either team. Assuming a NE vs MIN Superbowl, I think NE's experience and game script gives them a slight edge. MIN has the benefit (in this scenario) of de facto homefield advantage as they are hosting the Superbowl, and that bolsters their odds of keeping pace with NE.  We'll see how Sunday shakes out.

The only team with an established quarterback are the New England Patriots. The Patriot defense will have a field day against their lesser equipped opponents. IMO, it's that simple, and not any more simple.

Football is something I know nothing about, but I recently happened to read an article about which wins games (defense or offense).  Since there's awesome forecasters at 538 who seem to do better than most of us at putting aside their hopes/fears when analyzing situations, I thought I'd give this a try by forecasting what 538 says. Here's the article, though, for folks who want to massage the numbers: https://theconversation.com/does-defense-actually-win-championships-89628?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Latest%20from%20The%20Conversation%20for%20January%2012%202018%20-%2092197826&utm_content=Latest%20from%20The%20Conversation%20for%20January%2012%202018%20-%2092197826+Version+B+CID_f87f0198f3076e3a5ec48393ca4e899d&utm_source=campaign_monitor_us&utm_term=Does%20defense%20actually%20win%20championships Does defense actually win championships?
January 12, 2018  Legendary football coach Paul “Bear” Bryant famously said, “Offense sells tickets. Defense wins championships.” . . . .The thinking goes that while offense may be flashy and exciting, solid defensive play – less noticeable, but more steady and predictable – forms the foundation of successful teams. So is there any truth to the adage? . . . To represent a team’s offensive ability, we used regular season yards gained per game; for defensive ability, we used the statistic of yards allowed per game. If defense wins championships, the teams that tend to allow the fewest yards over the course of a season should have the most playoff success. What did the numbers say? After running some regression analyses, we found that defense, indeed, does win championships. The fewer regular season yards a team allowed in the regular season, the more playoff wins they tended to have.
. . . 
The same analysis revealed that yards gained offensively during the season correlated similarly – nearly identically, in fact – with subsequent playoff success. It turns out we should probably amend the adage to say: “Really good defense wins championships. And really good offense also wins championships.”
. . . 
If you were to look at previous sport psychology research. . . Most studies of why athletes might either “choke” or be “clutch” under pressure had tested fine motor skills such as field goal kicking in football and free throw shooting in basketball. On the other hand, defensive skills typically require more footwork and continuous movement, and – in the case of a defensive lineman or a linebacker in football – physical strength. For this reason, it was generally assumed that defensive play might be more stable, and less susceptible to pressure when seasons are on the line. If this were true, then the play of good defensive teams would remain steady during the playoffs, while good offensive teams would be more vulnerable to pressure-packed situations. So what might explain why our findings suggest otherwise? It may be that defensive players feel the pressure just as much as offensive players do, with their performance prone to the same fluctuations. After all, most burly defensive linemen aren’t just blindly crashing into the line; rather, they’re moving with the precision of a ballet dancer. At the very least, when it comes to dealing with pressure, it probably doesn’t matter if you’re a cornerback or a quarterback; sport psychology research has shown that athletes who feel confident and in control are more likely to give a clutch performance. When it’s all on the line, which side of the ball you’re on might matter less than your ability to feel in control. . . .  Maybe we just haven’t looked at football under the microscope carefully enough, and it’s worth analyzing whether specific positions or actions – throwing a football, protecting the pocket, covering a wide receiver – are more vulnerable to pressure. Maybe “offensive line play wins championships,” or “quarterbacking wins championships.”

I see New England as 80% likely to win against Jacksonville and 70% likely to win against either Minnesota or Philadelphia.  That gets them to about 55%.  If Minnesota and Philadelphia are each at 50% likely to win their match and 30% chance of winning the Superbowl, that gets them in at about 15% each.
